title: AMD Ryzen 3 8300G vs AMD Ryzen 5 5600G - Which wins?
text: It's the battle between the AMD Ryzen 3 8300G vs AMD Ryzen 5 5600G PC Guide is reader-supported. When you buy through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Prices subject to change. Read More Last Updated on February 2, 2024 AMD has finally revealed its Ryzen 3 8300G, primed for worldwide release in Q1 of 2024. Ever since its release, people have been comparing it with another AMD processor from the 5000 series, including the Ryzen 5 5600G. In this comparison article, we will put AMD Ryzen 3 8300G vs AMD Ryzen 5 5600G in a showdown to see which wins and which one we recommend for users of all backgrounds. We’ll delve into specs, performance, and cost to get a full picture of how both models shape up for your desktop. For additional desktop APUs and Ryzen 5000 series content, be sure to check out our recommendations for the best Ryzen 5000 series CPU in 2024. First, though, let’s start here. The Ryzen 3 8300G and the Ryzen 5 5600G belong to different generations and exhibit noticeable differences in their core specifications. The Ryzen 3 8300G is built on the AM5 socket and features a cutting-edge 4 nm processor size. It comprises 4 cores and 8 threads, with a base frequency of 3.4 GHz and a boost frequency of 4.9 GHz. It boasts 64K of L1 cache per core, 1MB of L2 cache per core, and 8MB of shared L3 cache. The graphics card/GPU component comprises 256 shading units, offering respectable graphical processing capabilities. On the other hand, the Ryzen 5 5600G is built on the AM4 socket and utilizes a 7 nm processor size. It boasts 6 cores and 12 threads, providing enhanced multitasking prowess compared to its counterpart. The base clock is 100 MHz higher than the Ryzen 3 8300G at 3.9 GHz, with a boost frequency of up to 4.4 GHz. It offers 64KB of L1 cache per core, 512KB of L2 cache per core, and a generous 16MB of L3 cache. With 448 shading units, the Ryzen 5 5600G can cancel out the graphical performance of any device. Additionally, memory and PCIe up to 256 GB of memory in a maximum of 2 memory channels is supported by the AMD Ryzen 3 8300G, while the AMD Ryzen 5 5600G supports a maximum of 64 GB of memory with a maximum memory bandwidth of 51.2 GB/s enabled. The performance disparity between the Ryzen 3 8300G and the Ryzen 5 5600G is evident due to variations in core count, cache sizes, and processing capabilities. The Ryzen 5 5600G has a PassMark benchmark performance score of 19902 for multi-core performance and 3191 for single-core performance. Although the performance scores for the Ryzen 3 8300G are not available, they are expected to be lower than that of the Ryzen 5 5600G. The Ryzen 5 5600G’s additional cores and threads provide a significant advantage in multitasking scenarios and CPU-intensive workloads. With 50% more cores and threads than the Ryzen 3 8300G, the Ryzen 5 5600G showcases superior performance in tasks such as video editing, 3D rendering, and software compilation. Moreover, the Ryzen 5 5600G’s larger cache sizes facilitate quicker data access, resulting in smoother operation and reduced latency compared to the Ryzen 3 8300G. The more shading units in the Ryzen 5 5600G enhance its graphical prowess, making it a more compelling choice for gamers and content creators seeking fluid gaming experiences and accelerated multimedia processing. The pricing dynamics play a pivotal role in determining the overall value proposition of the Ryzen 3 8300G and the Ryzen 5 5600G. While the launch price of the Ryzen 5 5600G was $259, the exact price of the Ryzen 3 8300G remains undisclosed. However, industry experts speculate it will likely be priced under $250, positioning it as a cost-effective solution for budget-conscious consumers. Considering the performance differentials between the two processors, the Ryzen 5 5600G justifies its higher price tag with its superior computing capabilities and enhanced graphical performance. For users prioritizing seamless multitasking, intensive workloads, and immersive gaming experiences, the Ryzen 5 5600G emerges as a compelling investment, offering exceptional value for its price. However, for users with more modest computing requirements or constrained budgets, the Ryzen 3 8300G presents a viable alternative, delivering commendable performance at a more accessible price point. From our research, the most appropriate motherboards for your AMD Ryzen 5 5600G include the ASUS ROG Crosshair VIII Hero, MSI MEG X570 Godlike, and the ASRock X570 Phantom Gaming X. This is because these models offer solid overclocking features and are designed to handle high-performance CPUs. In the showdown between the AMD Ryzen 3 8300G and the AMD Ryzen 5 5600G, the latter emerges as the clear winner in terms of performance, offering a potent combination of higher core count, larger cache sizes, and superior graphical capabilities for your PC. By our calculations, the Ryzen 5 5600G excels in multitasking scenarios, content creation platforms, and gaming experiences, making it an ideal choice for enthusiasts and power users seeking uncompromising performance. However, the Ryzen 3 8300G presents a compelling option for budget-conscious consumers and entry-level users looking to balance affordability and performance. With its competitive pricing and respectable specifications, the Ryzen 3 8300G offers a gateway to the world of AMD Ryzen processors without breaking the bank.
